# 'Supreme Court Ethics' Achieves Oxymoron Status
## Also more mandatory office policies and a brief primer on the Federal Circuit controversy.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJuly 19, 2023 at 4:16 PMJuly 19, 2023 at 1:21 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/supreme-court-ethics-achieves-oxymoron-status/&text=‘Supreme%20Court%20Ethics’%20Achieves%20Oxymoron%20Status)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/supreme-court-ethics-achieves-oxymoron-status/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/supreme-court-ethics-achieves-oxymoron-status/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg)

The Supreme Court’s ethical lapses reached such heights that a fellow federal judge had to step in to [publicly ask what’s wrong with these people](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/federal-judge-absolutely-nails-supreme-courts-ethics-dumpster-fire/). And it’s not just the big ticket scandals anymore, with the Court’s reputation so tarnished that folks freak out over non-scandals (or at the most minor ones) like [Venmogate](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/maybe-the-guardian-should-leave-the-clarence-thomas-exposes-to-pro-publica/) and [Sonia’s Book Club](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/sonia-sotomayor-schools-conservative-supreme-court-justices-on-the-right-way-to-respond-to-an-ethics-inquiry/). Meanwhile, more Biglaw firms opt for a 4-day mandatory office policy, though there’s still not a lot of momentum behind the move. And Judge Pauline Newman of the Federal Circuit continues to fight against her colleagues for her right to continue to hear cases.

# Monday Night Money Party: Another Firm Announces Salary Hikes
## Who'd have thought that Monday night would be such a busy time for associate salary news?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 13, 2016 at 8:00 PM
22
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/monday-night-money-party-another-firm-announces-salary-hikes/&text=Monday%20Night%20Money%20Party:%20Another%20Firm%20Announces%20Salary%20Hikes)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/monday-night-money-party-another-firm-announces-salary-hikes/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/monday-night-money-party-another-firm-announces-salary-hikes/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Who’d have thought that Monday night would be such a busy time for associate salary news? Since 5:00 p.m. eastern Above the Law has received tips that 10(!) Biglaw firms have notified associates their base compensation will be increasing effective July 1.

The latest to join the party is Houston-based firm Bracewell. They are increasing salaries to the full Cravath scale, which gives all associates a pay raise of between $20,000 and $35,000, depending on class year, as set forth in the memo below. The class of 2016 and summer associates can also expect a bigger payday.

Reaction to the news has been very positive from the rank and file associates on the ground:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Early word is that associates are really pleased, especially in smaller markets like Seattle/San Antonio / Dallas. The firm had a down year last year (though it’s been a very busy 2016) so it’s great to see that they are still being generous to associates.

We are covering this story as market conditions develop, so please drop us a line — text (646-820-8477) or [email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”) — when you know of another firm making a compensation move. Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file. All sources are kept strictly confidential.

Kathryn Rubino is an editor at Above the Law. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Am Law 50 Firm Ponies Up Market Rate Special Bonuses -- For *Some* Associates
## Some folks are excited, at least.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 14, 2021 at 12:46 PMApril 15, 2021 at 3:32 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/am-law-50-firm-ponies-up-market-rate-special-bonuses-for-some-associates/&text=Am%20Law%2050%20Firm%20Ponies%20Up%20Market%20Rate%20Special%20Bonuses%20—%20For%20*Some*%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/am-law-50-firm-ponies-up-market-rate-special-bonuses-for-some-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/am-law-50-firm-ponies-up-market-rate-special-bonuses-for-some-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The special bonus trend is still ripping through Biglaw. The latest firm that made an announcement joining the ranks of firms handing out big cash to associates is Perkins Coie.

The Biglaw firm — ranked 45th in the Am Law 100 with $934,810,000 in 2019 gross revenue — recently [made headlines](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2021/04/09/perkins-coie-anticipating-hybrid-work-to-scale-back-office-footprint/) for deciding to scale back their physical office footprint, noting that hybrid work solutions are here to stay. Another thing here to stay are Biglaw special bonuses, and Perkins Coie has also saddled up to that trend.

Last week, Perkins Coie announced special bonuses. They’ve matched the prevailing market rate, ranging from $12,000 for first-year associates to $64,000 for ninth-year+ associates, divided up into two payments made in April and November of this year. Associates have to be in good standing and hit a 1950 hours requirement.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Well — for some associates.

As tipsters at the firm have noted, only major market offices are getting those big bonuses. Others are getting some bonus money, just not as large:

Bonuses are at market for Austin, Bellevue, Chicago, Dallas, Denver, LA, NY, Palo Alto, San Diego, San Fran, Seattle, and WDC. Bonuses for Anchorage, Boise, Madison, Phoenix, and Portland are only half of market. Associates getting reduced bonuses are, naturally, pretty pissed—but hardly surprised since we have become so used to being shit on related to salary and bonus decisions. So much for the “One Firm” model that they keep emphasizing to us, I guess.

Hm, sounds like morale — at least at those other markets — isn’t great.

# Getting Noticed As An Associate
## Every day is a chance to market yourself. Here are some tips to get you started.
By [Bruce Stachenfeld](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brucestachenfeld/)  
onMarch 28, 2019 at 1:44 PMMarch 28, 2019 at 11:45 AM
35
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/getting-noticed-as-an-associate/&text=Getting%20Noticed%20As%20An%20Associate)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/getting-noticed-as-an-associate/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/03/getting-noticed-as-an-associate/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As a younger attorney, focusing on proving yourself and doing a good job are very important, but so is developing a comfort level in interacting with the (more senior) people you are working for, whether it’s a senior partner or one of your clients.  Most junior lawyers don’t think about this. I know I didn’t. I did what I was told. Instead of being proactive, I was purely reactive. Was this a disaster?  No. But I bet I missed out on a lot of opportunities.

Consider the last meeting you were at where there was a partner running the meeting with the clients. Did you participate in the discussion or just sit quietly at the table?

Are you a believer in this view: “If you sit there quietly and say nothing people may ‘think’ you’re stupid but won’t be sure, but if you open your mouth you will remove all doubt about it.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Certainly, I was that way for many years. It was basically because I was intimidated and afraid to open my mouth for that very reason.

If you are quiet and passive and do great work, you will do okay, but if you are outspoken and positive you will do much better. Every day is a chance to market yourself.

Here are some thoughts:

- Practice an elevator pitch: Assume someone asked you something open-ended like:  “Hey Toby, tell me about yourself. What’s your story?”  What would you say?  You could talk about your sailing hobby, or you could talk about your career and desires. Maybe say something like:  “Well Bruce, I have been at the firm for a year and a half now and I really find myself just loving the joint venture deals. Don’t get me wrong, that I don’t like other stuff too, but the joint ventures seem to fit my personality and the way my brain works. It is sort of like playing chess in the future. I love those deals and hope I get a chance to do a lot more of them.”  Saying something like that makes an implied statement about you that you are smart, eager, focused, and developing key skills. If I were the partner in charge of you, I might not realize it at that moment, but I would certainly be earmarking you for more work on joint ventures.

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
 

- Introduce yourself: If there is a meeting, introduce yourself confidently with an appropriate handshake and make eye contact. “Hi, my name is Toby. I am Bruce’s associate on this deal. I am really looking forward to working with you on this.”
 

- Ask your colleagues: If you are treated like a potted plant at meetings by the partner you work with, screw up your courage and ask the partner. Maybe something like:  “You know, Bruce, I appreciate the chance to work on the deals, but one concern I have is that I don’t get a real chance to participate in the meetings. I would love it if maybe you could include me in the conversations a bit. I assure you I won’t let you down and say something foolish.”  This may go nowhere I admit, but it may go somewhere you should admit. In any case, you have little to lose in having this conversation and perhaps everything to gain.
 

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
- Learn about your industry: As I have said repeatedly in prior articles, knowledge is power. So learn everything you can about your industry. If you know the topic du jour it is much easier to participate.
 

- Something gutsy and creative: Before you go into the meeting with a client and the partner, Google the client and learn about her. Perhaps she has a charity she supports. Imagine how cool you will look when you say: “Hi, my name is Toby. I am Bruce’s associate on this deal. I am really looking forward to working with you on this. Also, I looked you up before our meeting and we share a passion in saving whales. I am really impressed with your work on the Save the Whales Initiative.”
 

- Connect with the other associate: Okay, perhaps the team at the table is just above your pay grade or you are just too intimidated to speak to a captain of industry when you are a junior associate. Fair enough. However, certainly, you aren’t afraid to speak to the other junior associate in the room. Possibly she feels the same way. So go ahead and make a friend. Someday she may be your biggest client or you may be hers. You are playing in the same sandbox so build a sand castle together.
 

- If you have an idea, say it for heaven’s sake: I am sure you have been sitting in a meeting and you think you have a thought or perspective that no one else has. It is bubbling up and you are almost about to speak, but you just chicken out and then the moment passes and it is too late, and you missed your chance. Next time that happens, just don’t do that. Speak!  Let it fly. The worst that happens is your idea is a dud and, okay, you don’t have the happiest feeling. But if it is a good thought, well, then suddenly you are participating in the conversation
Ultimately, the advice here comes down to one thing, which is not being afraid. I admit I was afraid for years as a junior associate as it is completely natural in a new unfamiliar setting. But you don’t have to make the same mistakes I made. So I urge you to go for it and see what happens.

[Bruce Stachenfeld](http://dsllp.com/attorneys/29/) is the chairman of [Duval & Stachenfeld LLP](http://www.dsllp.com/), an approximately 50-lawyer law firm based in midtown Manhattan with one of the largest real estate law practices in New York City.  The Firm is known as “The Pure Play in Real Estate Law” because all of its practice areas are focused around real estate. You can contact Bruce by email at [thehedgehoglawyer@gmail.com](mailto:thehedgehoglawyer@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column). Bruce also writes The Real Estate Philosopher™, which contains applications of Bruce’s eclectic, insightful, and outside-the-box thinking to the real estate world. If you would like to read previous articles or subscribe, please click [here](http://dsllp.com/about/the_real_estate_philosopher.php).

# Magic Circle Firm’s London Office Welcomes Big-Time Bonuses To Compete With U.S. Firms
## Allen & Overy is making money moves across the pond.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 24, 2021 at 2:14 PMNovember 24, 2021 at 12:28 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/magic-circle-firms-london-office-welcomes-big-time-bonuses-to-compete-with-u-s-firms/&text=Magic%20Circle%20Firm’s%20London%20Office%20Welcomes%20Big-Time%20Bonuses%20To%20Compete%20With%20U.S.%20Firms)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/magic-circle-firms-london-office-welcomes-big-time-bonuses-to-compete-with-u-s-firms/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/magic-circle-firms-london-office-welcomes-big-time-bonuses-to-compete-with-u-s-firms/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
 Our London bonus plan also allows flexibility to award a limited number of larger bonuses to associates and counsel for outstanding contribution through activities that add significant value to the business.

— A spokesman for Allen & Overy, commenting on the Magic Circle firm’s new year-end bonus plan for its London associates, which is part of A&O’s efforts to compete with U.S.-based Biglaw firms with London offices. According to [The Lawyer](https://www.thelawyer.com/allen-overy-creates-new-bonus-plan-for-leveraged-finance-associates/), these bonuses will be offered only to leveraged finance associates, while the firm’s spokesman told [Bloomberg Law](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/wake-up-call-a-o-says-london-associates-to-get-bonuses) that all London associates would be eligible. No bonus specific bonus scale was mentioned.

# Trending: Cryptocurrency In Employee Compensation And Benefits
## PLI has put together a program to address the issues raised by integrating crypto into compensation and 401(k) plans.
By STEPHANIE WILKINS  
onJune 22, 2022 at 4:46 PMJune 22, 2022 at 4:35 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/trending-cryptocurrency-in-employee-compensation-and-benefits/&text=Trending:%20Cryptocurrency%20In%20Employee%20Compensation%20And%20Benefits)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/trending-cryptocurrency-in-employee-compensation-and-benefits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/trending-cryptocurrency-in-employee-compensation-and-benefits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Cryptocurrency has been around for more than a decade, and it only continues to evolve and grow in popularity. Bitcoin may have ruled the scene in the early days, but today there are [over 18,000](https://www.investopedia.com/tech/most-important-cryptocurrencies-other-than-bitcoin/) cryptocurrencies on the market.

While crypto may once have been dismissed as frivolous or something that would never expand beyond the realm of the most internet-savvy, today it plays a legitimate role in business. Many companies now accept payment in cryptocurrency. Furthermore, an increasing number of municipalities around the world are recognizing cryptocurrency as legal tender and have even dabbled in launching their own cryptocurrencies.

It was just a matter of time, then, until employees started discussing the idea of integrating crypto into their compensation and 401(k) retirement plans. As with all benefits and compensation issues, this raises a number of ethical and legal considerations.

PLI has put together a program to address those issues. In a one-hour program entitled [Employee Compensation and Benefits Involving Cryptocurrency: Trends and Legal Issues](https://www.pli.edu/programs/employee-compensation-and-benefits-involving-cryptocurrency-trends-and-legal-issues?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2), Shawn Butte, in-house employment counsel at Wish, will provide an overview of the legal issues governing the payment of wages or bonuses to employees in cryptocurrency and the addition of cryptocurrency as an election option in a 401(k) plan.

Topics to be covered include:

- Cryptocurrency definitions, including Bitcoin, Ethereum, and stablecoins
- Cryptocurrency transaction basics
- Potential benefits to employers with allowing employees to receive wages or bonuses in cryptocurrency
- Legal risks to consider when paying employees in cryptocurrency
- Examining how the volatility of cryptocurrency could impact an employer’s compliance with wage and hour laws
- The possible impact on classification of employees as exempt or non-exempt
- The Department of Labor’s recent guidance expressing concerns with adding cryptocurrencies as an election option to a 401(k) plan
- Recent trends involving the adoption and regulation of cryptocurrency, including its adoption by municipalities worldwide and the SEC’s plans to regulate cryptocurrency
- Requirements for 401(k) plans under the Economic Retirement Income Security Act (“ERISA”)
The potential of offering employees the option to receive wages or invest in cryptocurrency through their 401(k) is an exciting development in the benefits space, but it’s important to understand the related legal and ethical issues. [Register today](https://www.pli.edu/programs/employee-compensation-and-benefits-involving-cryptocurrency-trends-and-legal-issues?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2) to learn more about this cutting-edge area of the law.

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/in-house-counsel/), [Litigators](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/litigators/), [On Course](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/on-course/), [On Course Practice](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/on-course-practice/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/)
